texts.shortText: The South African material was described as Pholas jordani by van Hoepen (1941), but that species was subsequently merged with P. dactylus, which is a European species, by Barnard (1964). Recent research by the Sea Change group has shown that the South African form is genetically distinct from the European one and hence the original name needs to be re-erected for local material. This has not yet been formally done though, so at the time of writing the official name remains P. dactylus.

Highly distinctive and iconic species with elongate, pure white shell that gapes widely at anterior end. There are a pair of unique accessory shell plates covering the hinge, and a row of exterior partitions above the hinge, which allow even fragments of dead shell to be positively identified. The exterior of the shell is ornamented with concentric rows of sharp pricky ridges, which are used to file away the rock and form the burrow. Also readily identified by its unusual habit of excavating deep, tapering burrows onto soft sandstone and limestone.

Global: Jordani form endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to about East London.

Excavate elongate, linear, tapering burrows deep into soft rocks. The burrow is created by rocking the shells against the walls of the burrow such that the sharp, rasp-like prickles on the exterior of the shell erode away the rock. As the animal grows, the burrow is extended deeper into the rock and becomes progressively wider, reaching to at least 20 cm depth in large individuals. The large siphons project from the gaping anterior end of the shell and reach our through the small aperture into the overlying water.

 Apart from their unusual rock-burrowing habits, piddocks are also well known for their ability to produce  a luminous mucus. The European species has been extensively exploited for human consumption since Roman times and as extracting and collecting piddocks involves destruction of their habitat, the species is now endangered and strictly protected in Europe. As only a small number of live colonies are known to exist in South Africa, these should probably also be protected against similar over-exploitation.

As with most bivalves filter-feed by sucking water in through an inhalant siphon, filtering out fine food particles by passing the water though the enlarged sieve-like gills and then ejecting waste water though a exhalent siphon.
Broadcast spawners, ejecting sperm and eggs into the water column, where they merge to form pelagic larvae to drift in the plankton and settle in other suitable sites.

Unlikely to be confused with other species due to the unusual rock-boring habits and unusual shell structure. Burrows are sometimes confused with those created by another rock boring species Petricola bicolar, but piddock burrows are much deeper, linear and tapering, while those of Petricola are shallow and cup shaped.

Barnard, KH (1964). Contributions to the knowledge of South African marine Mollusca V. Lamellibranchiata. Annals of the South African Museum, 47, 361-593.
